alert.note: Alert for Oconee (South Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Greenville-Spartanburg (Western North Carolina and Northwest South Carolina)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued September 03 at 11:08AM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT UNTIL 2 PM EDT THIS AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is occurring. * WHERE...Portions of northeast Georgia and Upstate South Carolina, including the following counties, in northeast Georgia, Rabun. In upstate South Carolina, Oconee. * WHEN...Until 200 PM EDT. * IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is imminent or occurring. Numerous roads are either water covered or closed due to flooding. Some low-water crossings are inundated with water and may not be passable. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1100 AM EDT, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges indicated additional light to moderate rainfall, which is following earlier torrential rainfall. Flooding is already occurring in the warned area. Between 2 and 6 inches of rain have fallen over the past six hours. Light to moderate rain showers continue in a few locations, with localized additional amounts up to an inch still possible into the early afternoon. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Walhalla, Westminster, Sky Valley, Tallulah Falls, Oconee State Park, Tallulah Gorge State Park, Lake Hartwell, Mountain Rest, Long Creek, Pine Mountain, Oakway, Scaly Mountain and Bad Creek. Flooding is most likely along the Tugaloo River, Chauga River, Little Toxaway Creek, Longnose Creek, Coneross Creek and other tributaries from Mountain Rest to Westminster and points west. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
info.instruction: When it is safe to do so, please report flooding or landslides threatening roads or property to the National Weather Service Greenville-Spartanburg by calling toll free, 1, 800, 2 6 7, 8 1 0 1, by posting on our Facebook page, or via Twitter using hashtag NWSGSP. Your message should describe the specific location where impacts occurred and the depth of flooding observed. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles.
